abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings indicate an unsatisfactory
            project outcome, unlikely sustainability, negligible
            institutional development impacts, and unsatisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. The unsuccessful
            project results draws many lessons, of which some follows.
            Specifically reinforced are issues concerning the critical
            aspects of: Bank responsiveness to the client needs,
            particularly legal documents related to restructuring
            amendments requested by the Government; maintaining a
            constant transparent dialogue with the client, to understand
            the reasons for certain decisions; clear Project design and
            objectives; and, personnel changes, that may affect the
            project in a negative way. Other lessons include the need
            for more flexible procurement and disbursement procedures,
            specifically for emergency operations. Conventional
            procurement and disbursement rules cannot be applied in a
            country, where agencies have no incentive to submit invoices
            or to identify eligible investments. Projects that finance
            small sub-projects should simplify financial management
            processes, especially those related to the validation of
            disbursements and expenditures. And, since very few
            countries are really prepared to engage in disaster risk
            management, the Bank should pay specific attention to this
            issue, and ramp up its efforts to train Bank staff, and
            Borrowers on this issue. Even though mitigation measures
            bring about major benefits, they have not been incorporated
            into the planning of sustainable development in countries
            repeatedly affected by disasters, such as the case in Mexico.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Natural Disaster Management
            Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Disaster Management Project
            will provide resources for post-diaster emergency recovery
            and reconstruction financed by the Fund for Natural
            Disasters (FONDEN) through the mixed state trusts (FMEs). No
            eligible subprojects are expected to have significant
            adverse environmental impacts. This environmental management
            plan (EMP) includes the following: 1) It describes
            Mexico's environmental regulations and institutional
            arrangements for environment assessment (EA), especially as
            they apply to emergency recovery and reconstruction
            subprojects not normally subject to prior review by the
            Bank. 2) It assesses institutional capacity to carry out EA
            and provides a negative list of subprojects that the project
            will not finance and a positive list of subprojects that it
            can. 3) It outlines proposed EA arrangements for each type
            of subprojects financed by the project, describing how
            cultural property will be treated and how public
            consultation will occur. 4) It sets out the procedures for
            reporting and Bank supervision and monitoring, and outlines
            contemplated capacity development activities.

717416.trustfund:
TF025947-MIGA-ENHANCING FLOWS OF FOREIGN
            DIRECT INVESTMENT TO ASIA,TF025844-PHRD-NATURAL DISASTER MANAGEMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Natural Disaster Management Project,
            will help reduce human, economic, and financial costs of
            natural disasters in Mexico, by providing resources for
            rapid recovery - under sound budgetary management -
            following natural disasters, and, will reduce the likelihood
            of life losses, and infrastructure damage resulting from
            natural forces, by supporting policy, and institutional
            reforms, aimed at reducing natural disaster risks, and
            vulnerability. The project components will: 1) finance
            analytical design, and policy-related studies, and
            equipment, aimed at reducing economic, and human losses
            resulting from natural disaster events. In accordance with
            the Bank, and executing agencies, the Secretaria de Hacienda
            y Credito Publico (SHCP) will agree on financing preventive
            activities, selected within the Bank's technical
            criteria, in the areas of capacity building, land use
            management plans, building standards, and natural resources
            management; 2) support emergency recovery, and
            reconstruction activities, to be financed by the Fund for
            Natural Disasters (FONDEN) through the mixed state trusts
            (FMEs). These activities are subject to expedited
            procurement procedures, and, related investments will be
            selected in accordance to the Bank's procurement
            practices; and, 3) strengthen capacity of federal agencies,
            to be responsive to natural disasters, manage social and
            environmental issues, and, appropriately use risk transfer instruments.
